8.text:
Travelling by plane can be exciting
for some people

11.text: but for others it can be very challenging.

14.text: It can cause great stress and anxiety.

17.text:
This can be the case
for a person with autism,

20.text:
but also for their parents, carers
or people who are  travelling with them.

24.text:
Birmingham Airport and OCS
are keen to support these people

29.text:
and ensure everything possible
can be done to assist them

31.text:
when using the airport
and its facilities.

35.text:
There are some mandatory procedures
for air travel customers,

38.text:
such as the security systems,
passport and immigration control.

43.text:
However, Birmingham Airport, OCS and
Autism West Midlands have worked closely

48.text:
to make any reasonable adjustments
to their processes and procedures

52.text:
to take into account challenges
faced by people with autism

58.text:
This video will serve as a walkthrough
guide for Birmingham Airport,

62.text:
from arriving and checking in
to boarding the plane and departing.

66.text:
There will also be a short guide
of the arrivals process.

72.text:
offer escorted assistance for people
with autism, by prior arrangement.

76.text:
We will show an OCS assistant
escorting a passenger with autism

82.text:
but families and small groups
can also use this facility.

85.text:
This will give you the opportunity to
familiarise yourself with what to expect

91.text:
and give a good visual guide
of the processes.

94.text:
If you would like more general
information about autism,

97.text:
please visit
the Autism West Midlands website.

103.text:
There are several ways you may
travel to the airport:

111.text:
or a lift from a family member
or friend.

114.text:
You will need to make your way
to the departures hall.

117.text:
This may involve a walk
or a bus from the car park

121.text:
or a trip on the monorail
from the rail station.

123.text:
Taxis and buses pull up outside
the departure hall.

128.text:
If you need a trolley,
you will see signs

130.text:
showing where the trolley stations
are located.

134.text:
There are three entrances
to the departures hall.

137.text: Inside can be a very busy place.

139.text:
Lots of people will be moving through
as well as waiting around.

144.text:
Inside the departures hall,
you will find shops,

147.text: food and coffee outlets, waiting areas

150.text:
and, most importantly,
the OCS assistance desk.

153.text:
This is where you can speak to staff
about your travel through the airport,

159.text:
get any information
or access special equipment.

163.text:
You can also meet with your guide
if you have arranged an escort.

167.text:
The trained OCS assistance staff
will be at this desk,

170.text:
but will also be located
around the airport halls,

174.text:
wearing bright yellow tops
with the OCS logo.

177.text:
Please feel free to approach
any of them for help or guidance.

186.text:
This is the check-in hall and will be
the first queue you will encounter.

191.text:
The queuing system may appear strange
as it is not straight line.

196.text:
Passengers are guided through a winding
line through the queuing section.

200.text: There can be a significant wait

202.text:
so you may wish to provide
a quiet activity to pass the time.

207.text:
Also make sure you have made
a visit to the toilet if necessary,

213.text:
You may have arranged
for escorted assistance from OCS

217.text:
and this could include being taken
to the front of the queue.

220.text:
Checking-in is the process of confirming
you are prepared for the flight,

225.text: where your flight documents are checked

227.text:
and you will be issued with a
boarding pass to get on the plane later.

231.text:
This is also where you drop off
large luggage

234.text:
that will be put on the plane for you,
in its cargo section.

239.text:
and confirmed as below the limit set
for your journey.

243.text:
If your luggage weighs more, you may
be asked to pay an additional charge.

248.text:
Your luggage will pass through
to an area behind the desks,

252.text: to be taken to the plane.

254.text:
You will be allowed to take hand luggage
onto the plane with you,

258.text:
but the amount, size
and weight will be limited.

264.text:
on what items are allowed to be taken on
the plane with you in hand luggage

268.text:
as well as any loose items
you may carry.

275.text:
The next part of the process
is the security checking area.

280.text:
This is a very important process
that everyone has to do

283.text:
and is for the safety
of all air travellers.

286.text:
There will be another queue to join
and waiting times can vary a lot.

290.text:
It may be noisy and crowded
with warm, even high, temperatures.

295.text:
Again, it will be important to check
you have none of the prohibited items.

301.text:
When you arrive
at the security check area,

303.text:
you will be asked to do several things
that may feel uncomfortable or unusual,

308.text:
but these things are important
for all air travellers to ensure safety.

313.text:
You will be asked to place hand luggage
or bags into a special tray.

319.text:
You will also have to place loose items,
like phones, electronic devices,

323.text:
keys, coins and any other metallic items
into this tray.

328.text:
You may even be asked
to remove your shoes, belts,

332.text:
brooches or tie-pins,
if they are metallic or have metal on.

337.text:
The tray will then pass through
a machine that can see inside your bag

343.text:
You will then be asked to individually
pass through a big arch,

347.text: that is a metal detector machine,

349.text:
to check you haven't forgotten
to place any items in the tray,

352.text:
but sometimes an alarm sound will go off
as you pass through the arch.

356.text:
This will indicate
to the security people

359.text:
that there is still something metallic
on you or in your pocket.

362.text:
If this happens, there will be
an additional check

365.text: made by an individual security person.

367.text:
You may be asked to allow a security
person

369.text:
to rub a small piece of cloth
on your shoes

372.text:
This swab will then be placed
into a detector machine

375.text:
and will check for any prohibited
chemicals or substances.

379.text:
Once scanner checks are completed,
you'll be asked to collect your items

383.text:
from your tray
at the end of the conveyor.

386.text:
The conveyor system is often quite loud
and clunky.

393.text:
After the security checks,
you'll be offered the opportunity

395.text:
to buy things
in the tax & duty-free shopping area.

399.text:
This is called airside where you can buy
many items at a lower price than in high street stores

404.text: because you are technically out of the country.

407.text:
However there may be restrictions on how much of
certain things

413.text:
The tax & duty-free shopping area can be
somewhat overwhelming

417.text:
because there are many bright lights,
strong smells,

420.text:
and lots of people moving around
the stalls and through the walkways.

424.text:
Even if you do not want
to buy any items here,

426.text:
it can take a while to get through
this area to the departure lounge.

431.text:
OCS and Autism West Midlands have made
special arrangements with Birmingham Airport

435.text:
to allow people with autism and their
companions to bypass the tax & duty-free area

440.text: and go straight to the departure lounge.

443.text:
This does not mean that you cannot go
back into the tax & duty-free shopping area later on,

449.text:
once you have settled
in the departure lounge.

452.text:
This bypass option
is only by special prior arrangement

455.text:
and you will have to be escorted
by OCS staff through a special route.

460.text:
Please contact OCS before you arrive
at the airport to arrange this.

468.text:
Once in the departure lounge, you will
have several services available.

473.text:
You will have access to seating,
toilets, food and refreshment outlets,

478.text:
an area where you can watch planes
taking off and landing

485.text:
There will also be many large screens
with upcoming flight information,

489.text:
including the gate number you will need
to go to in order to board your plane.

494.text:
There will also be regular loudspeaker
announcements for passengers

498.text: to make their way to a particular gate,

500.text:
but not all of these
will be for your flight.

504.text: Whilst you are in the departure lounge,

506.text:
it will be good to check you have
all documents for boarding the plane.

511.text:
This will include the boarding passes
you were given at the check-in desk,

517.text:
While waiting, you may wish to check out
one of the great Sky Zone play areas.

523.text:
Here, you and your child
or young person,

525.text:
can pass waiting time, playing games or
doing interactive or sensory activities.

531.text:
Please visit the Sky Zone page on
Birmingham Airport's website

537.text:
Keep an eye on the flight information
screens

539.text: for when you are due to board

540.text:
and which gate you will need
to join the queue for.

544.text:
Once you are called to your boarding
gate by loudspeaker announcement,

547.text:
or you have seen the screen information
for your flight change to 'Boarding',

551.text:
you can then make your way
to the designated gate.

555.text: There will probably be a queue

557.text:
but you can arrange to be escorted
to the front of the queue

560.text:
by contacting OCS
before you arrive at the airport.

565.text:
you will be greeted by someone who will
ask you to show them your documents.

569.text:
Once these are checked,
you will proceed to the plane.

575.text:
There are several ways you may get
to the plane itself.

579.text:
Usually, you will go through
a short tunnel up to the plane door.

583.text:
You may be shown to a bus
that will take you to the plane.

587.text:
You might have to walk a short distance
to the plane and up steps to the door.

592.text:
At the door, you will be greeted
by a flight attendant,

595.text:
who may also ask you to show them your
boarding pass,

598.text:
which will let them know what seats
you are to go to.

601.text:
They will either tell you
the way to your seat,

604.text:
or may escort you there,
if necessary.

606.text:
Once in your seat, you will be required
to put on your seatbelt,

612.text:
and make sure any loose items are stowed
away in your hand luggage.

617.text:
You will be allowed to access these
and use your devices

620.text:
once the plane has taken off and the
'Seatbelts On' instruction is lifted.

624.text:
Above your seat, you will have a light
and an air vent.

628.text:
There will also be a blind that you
can pull down to cover the window,

631.text: if you are next to one.

633.text:
Once all the passengers
are on the plane,

635.text:
one of the flight attendants
will demonstrate

640.text: There is no need to worry about this.

642.text:
It is important information and this
demonstration happens on every flight.

647.text:
The plane will start to move slowly,
usually backwards at first,

651.text:
and will taxi slowly across the airfield
to where the plane will take off.

655.text:
When the plane is ready to take off, you
will hear a loud roar from the engines

659.text: and there may be some vibration.

661.text:
The plane will start to move
and accelerate faster and faster

664.text:
until it points upwards at an angle
and lifts off the runway.

668.text:
Shortly after the plane
leaves the ground,

670.text:
you may hear a clunking noise
from underneath the plane.

673.text:
This is the plane's wheels
being pulled up into the plane,

676.text: with the doors closing to cover them.

678.text:
You may feel a sensation
in your stomach,

681.text: like you get in a lift,

683.text:
and you may feel yourself
becoming a bit heavier.

687.text:
you may feel a popping sensation
in your ears.

690.text:
This is normal
but does not happen to everyone.

693.text:
This may continue for a while as
the plane climbs to its full altitude.

701.text:
If you are landing at Birmingham Airport
or returning from a trip away,

706.text:
this section will guide you
through the process.

709.text:
You might leave the plane
in a number of ways.

711.text:
Usually through a short tunnel
but maybe down some steps to a bus

715.text: or a short walk to the arrivals area.

718.text:
Birmingham Airport also offer
an assisted passenger service,

721.text:
which could include someone
meeting you on the plane

724.text:
and escorting you through
the rest of the arrival process.

727.text:
You will then proceed to the immigration
and passport control area,

731.text:
where your documents will be checked
by Border Force personnel.

735.text:
You could be faced by a long wait in a
winding queue

738.text:
and there will be lots of people
in official uniforms

740.text:
a bit like police officers,
making sure everyone is safe.

744.text:
You will eventually go to a desk where
an officer will check your documents.

748.text:
You will then pass through
into the luggage collection hall,

751.text:
where you will be shown
which carousel to collect from,

755.text: on big screens with your flight number.

757.text:
You will pass through
the customs area,

759.text:
where you may be asked to allow
an officer to look at your luggage

762.text: in case you have any prohibited items.

765.text:
After this, you will enter the arrivals
area in the main building.

769.text:
If you have arranged to meet someone,
this is where they will be.

773.text:
You can arrange for an OCS assistant
to escort you through the whole process

777.text:
up to this point,
by prior arrangement.

780.text:
Birmingham Airport, OCS
and Autism West Midlands

784.text:
hope that this video guide will help you
to prepare for your journey

787.text:
and give you a better idea of what to
expect travelling through the airport.

791.text:
OCS staff will be happy to assist you
at any point,

795.text:
just look out for the bright yellow tops
with the OCS logo.
